result.markdown:
---
title: JAX vs NumPy
author: Marie-Hélène Burle
---

[NumPy](https://numpy.org/) is a popular Python scientific API at the core of a lot of libraries. It is fast, written in Python and C, and provides the `ndarray` data type.

JAX uses a similar API with additional constraints.

Being familiar with NumPy is thus an advantage to get started with JAX. [The NumPy quickstart](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/user/quickstart.html) is a good resource to get started with NumPy.



different Python types

JAX arrays are immutable

::: {.cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
import numpy as np

x = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
print(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[[0 1 2]
 [3 4 5]
 [6 7 8]]
```
:::
:::


::: {.cell execution_count=2}
``` {.python .cell-code}
import jax.numpy as jnp

y = jnp.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
print(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[[0 1 2]
 [3 4 5]
 [6 7 8]]
```
:::
:::


::: {.cell execution_count=3}
``` {.python .cell-code}
x[0, 0] = 9
print(x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[[9 1 2]
 [3 4 5]
 [6 7 8]]
```
:::
:::


::: {.cell execution_count=4}
``` {.python .cell-code}
y[0, 0] = 9
print(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
TypeError: '<class 'jaxlib.xla_extension.ArrayImpl'>' object does not support item assignment. JAX arrays are immutable. Instead of ``x[idx] = y``, use ``x = x.at[idx].set(y)`` or another .at[] method: https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_autosummary/jax.numpy.ndarray.at.html
```
:::
:::


::: {.cell execution_count=5}
``` {.python .cell-code}
y = y.at[0].set(10)
print(y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[[10 10 10]
 [ 3  4  5]
 [ 6  7  8]]
```
:::
:::
